video.title: Data Structures and Algorithms in JavaScript - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn common data structures and algorithms in this tutorial course. You will learn the theory behind them, as well as how to program them in JavaScript.

⭐️ Contents (link to code after title) ⭐️
⌨️ Stacks (00:21) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/yMBGbR?editors=0012
⌨️ Sets (09:03) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/dvGeeq?editors=0012
⌨️ Queues & Priority Queues (19:24) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/QpaQRG?editors=0012
⌨️ Binary Search Tree (26:03) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/ryKvEQ?editors=0011
⌨️ Binary Search Tree: Traversal & Height (39:34) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/ryKvEQ?editors=0011
⌨️ Hash Tables (53:19) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/VbYGMb?editors=0012
⌨️ Linked List (1:03:04) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/ybOvBq?editors=0011
⌨️ Trie (1:14:59) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/mmBNBd?editors=0011
⌨️ Heap (max and min) (1:27:29) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/JNvENQ?editors=0010
🔗 Heap visualization: https://www.cs.usfca.edu/~galles/visualization/Heap.html
⌨️ Graphs: adjacency list, adjacency matrix, incidence matrix (1:42:07) 
⌨️ Graphs: breadth-first search (1:46:45) https://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/XgrXvw?editors=0012

📄Data structures article by Beau Carnes: https://medium.freecodecamp.org/10-common-data-structures-explained-with-videos-exercises-aaff6c06fb2b
🐦Follow creator Beau Carnes on Twitter: https://twitter.com/carnesbeau

🔗Beau also made this Algorithms course from Manning Publications: https://www.manning.com/livevideo/algorithms-in-motion?a_aid=algmotion&a_bid=9022d293 (Promo code: 39carnes)

🎥And if you like robots and toys, check out Beau's other YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/robotfamily

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Gaurav Mall
topLevelComment.text: Great lesson Mo, A minor correction In BST example though (video at 36:56)....  Since BST is always sorted, node "23" can never have a right linking to a lesser value (in this case "19"). In this scenario value "19" should not be there at all. Also, removal of node in BST can be revisited. The replaced value should be the max of the subtree (so 23 can be safely treated as a new node to be replaced in left subtree for your scenario) . Happy Coding!

topLevelComment.author: Emmanuel Chukwu
topLevelComment.text:
The difference of sets algorithm only works when the shorter set is passed into the function because you use the first set to check for difference. That’s not proper because in real cases, you don’t know exactly what’s in the sets.

Set1 = [2,3]
Set2 = [3,5,6,7]

In your implementation, 

set1.difference(set2) returns [2]
Set2.difference(set1) returns [2,5,6,7]

Shouldn’t you test which set is longer and then use it to check for the difference?

If you implement it that way, 

set1.difference(set2) returns [2,5,6,7]
Set2.difference(set1) returns [2,5,6,7]

Foolproof.

topLevelComment.author: John Baker
topLevelComment.text:
39:34 Great stuff, but you are WRONG on the height of a tree. Using the min/max height method gives you wrong results on certain trees. The height of a node is considered the max-height of that node, and so for a tree to be balanced each nodes' left and right substree cannot have a height (max height) difference of more than 1.

For example, insert this in a tree in order (50, 40, 30, 45, 48, 100, 90, 120, 80, 95, 110, 130, 60)
in this case the tree is actually balanced, but your min/max method will say its NOT. because the min height is 2 and max height is 4, which is WRONG. I hope people see this.

replies.author: MCTV
replies.text:
A stack is an array basically. Its an acumullation of data in a list form. Arrays in javascript come with methods included to manipulate that Data. Array method PUSH adds data to that array or list, array method pop eliminates the last item in that list.

So if you have an array called myArray, and you want to add data in javascript you can simply do myArray.push("yournewdata"). And if you later want to remove the last item on your array you just simply do myArray.pop().

A black square as you see it here in reality is just to brackets [ ] which indicates an empty array. An array is just a list of data. 
So, in javascript arrays are simbolized with square brackets and the data goes inside separated by commas, like so: myArray = [1,2,3,4,5]

You might go to a more begginner topic though, if you did not know what I wrote before. You would benefit from some beginner javascript lessons more than this particular video.

replies.author: Selvaraj K
replies.text:
It was a bit difficult to understand this. Below details might improve your understanding.
..
How findMinHeight works?
1. Start from the bottom-most node. Add 1 when you level up.
2. Find the min-height until the current node. i.e. the bottom if-else case, which is also Math.min(left, right);
3. Repeat steps 1 & 2 until you reach the root node.
For findMaxHeight() just replace Math.min with Math.max
..
And, why the counting starts with -1 instead of 0?
Since the levels are calculated from 0 and not from 1.
..
..
Please upvote if this makes sense so that others can benefit as well.

replies.author: Anas N
replies.text: Because it uses recursion. Eventually the node will be null and return -1. So, the smallest number that will be returned by the method is -1 + 1 = 0.

Stack is just like Que except everything is done at the end. Que can be flip flopped. i.e. que can add to the top, take from the back, and vice versa. 


lookup documentation on sets for .has() and .every(). you implement it to check for the presence of elements in a specific array or for elements in common between arrays.

replies.author: Shahid Kamal
replies.text:
Let me try to put -
all findMinHeight is doing is traverse through left and right of each node from root and for each node it decides what to return. So for example 5 has 4 in left and 6 in right and 4 had 2 in left and 7 in right so findMinHeight would be called for 5(root) then it'll wait for findMinHeight (4) (node.left) then again it'll be paused until findMinHeight (2) returns something in findMinHeight (2) nothing is there so it'll return -1 since 2 is left of 4 then for node(4) we get `left = 0` same happens with right

replies.author: Rafael Rocha
replies.text:
Only the fact that you're polluting an already existing abstraction with an additional method that might or not translate well into other use cases.
Check prototypal pollution.
I would rather create a class that extends and use that one directly. 
Under the hood the behaviour is similar but semantically looks nicer and enables more extensible code.
Then again you're approach isn't wrong by any means but in a team context it wouldn't be preferable.

topLevelComment.author: Nil
topLevelComment.text: The Set implementation is not correct, you are using indexOf(), which has a time complexity of O(n). The real implementation of Set.add() uses hash tables,  which takes O(1). Deletion in the queue should take O(1), but your implementation takes O(n)

replies.author: Bryan Strader
replies.text: Just came across this and had a question, add and delete are O(1) when using hash tables, but when implemented using hash tables is the constructor always going to be O(n) when initially setting up the table of keys/values? That might just be a trade off, unless I am missing something.

replies.author: Abdulrahman Tolba
replies.text: @Nandhan Natarajan Sets are also used because they contain unique values, as opposed to filtering out duplicates in arrays. But yeah, they should utilize hash tables, most other programming languages call them HashSet

replies.author: Nandhan Natarajan
replies.text: @George L. I mean lets be honest sets should use hash tables. The only reason sets are used is to search for values in O(1). If Sets were O(n), there would be no point in using set over array.

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: Data structures are ways to hold data. For instance, a linked list is a data structure that stores sequential data that is 'linked' together. Most of the items in this video are types of data structures. An algorithm is code that acts on a data structure. For instance, the code to find an item in a binary search tree would be considered an algorithm.

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text:
Each node can only have two children. If the six slid up to where the three was, then the six would have three children: 1, 4, and 7. That is not allowed.

Your right, the link was missing. Just added. Here it is: https://www.cs.usfca.edu/~galles/visualization/Heap.html

Most people will not use graphs in JavaScript. However, they are used a lot in Deep Learning. All the concepts about graphs in this video will also apply with other programming languages.

replies.author: Valeriia Protsko
replies.text:
Actually, this is a good question, as not that many tutorials talk about this.  Yes, you can start from an online editor as was recommended earlier. 
There are a few options, depending on what you are trying to achieve. You do not need to install JavaSript, your browser understands it. Your task is to "explain" the browser that it has to run your code. 
 And there are a few other options:
1. To try some of the code based on the examples from this video, you can open DevTools in Chrome go to the console and type your code there.  
2. You can use any text editor and place your JavaScript code between <script> </script> tags and save a file as .html  and open the file with your browser. In this case, you can't use the console.log() to see the results, you will have to either pass this data to html elements or use alert() function. 
3. You can install node.js, save your code in .js file and run only JavaScript code by typing "node [file name]" and your results will be in the console.  If you want to work with HTML and CSS and manipulate the DOM,  you can use codepen.io or you can set up your own back-end part, for example, in node.js. AWS has a Simple storage solution that allows you to to host a static website. This can be a great practice as well, might envolve some small fees, especially if you want to use it for your portfolio.

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: You don't have to install JavaScript. It is included in all browsers. The easiest way to get started is with an online code editor like Codepen.io. If you are a beginner, I would recommend starting with the free curriculum at www.freecodecamp.org
